awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Nature of Hinterland Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award permits Mr. Nicholas Belluzzo to  investigate a pre-contact hinterland community on the island of Hawai'i. Researchers in Polynesia have long studied chiefly society and processes of sociopolitical formation.  Previous scholarship has often focused on archaeological records of core, chiefly centers, with models highlighting elite power strategies and authority. However, more recent scholarship increasingly focuses on understanding the common, non-elite role and agency in society. By virtue of their position beyond the margins of the royal centers, even less is known about how hinterland communities conceived of authority at both the local- and regional-scales or how this conception differed from the royal centers. Given that hinterland communities are less well represented in historical literature and ethnographic documentation, archaeological approaches are well situated to augment a more spatially comprehensive record of sociopolitical formation in Hawai'i. By deploying and re-defining the concept of hinterland, this project focuses specific attention on the agency, sources of authority, and social hierarchy of Hawaiian communities at multiple scales. The study re-frames depictions of hinterland communities from zones of resource extraction to intentional communities agentively negotiating local and regional interactions. As a multi-disciplinary effort, Mr. Belluzzo will collaborate with soil scientists, paleobotanists, authorities in traditional Hawaiian knowledge systems, and State land managers to develop a holistic research study while establishing cross-disciplinary research relationships.

This research frames hinterlands as neither frontiers nor borderlands, but locations situated between multiple sources of power and authority. By moving beyond monolithic core-periphery interactions, the research will investigate non-elite Hawaiian hinterland communities in the southern Kau District of Hawai'i Island using a "bottom-up" approach. This will highlight how agency and local authority created interactive communities not wholly subordinate to elite centers or political cores. The research will employ a landscape-based approach to assess the traditional Hawaiian land division of Manuka, situated at the intersection of two larger political districts in an environmentally uncertain region. This region will be evaluated to identify variation in community, agency, and authority using ethnographic, environmental, ecological, and archaeological data. Nick Belluzzo and his research team will collect data through a combination of archaeological survey, archival research, and test excavations to generate archaeological and environmental datasets. Geostatistical analysis will elicit patterns of authority and regional relationships in the archaic Hawaiian State. Specifically, this research will compare records of change and regional diversity in settlement and agricultural practices against expectations from more agriculturally productive core regions under direct, centralized chiefly rule. Both the results and syntheses of multiple novel methods will be broadly applicable to modeling social complexity in complex societies world-wide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Historical European accounts, elite Native Hawaiian historians, and oral traditions frame the Kaʻū District of Hawaiʻi Island as a marginal hinterland, interacting with the broader society but rejecting social and political norms. Frequently, this is attributed to marginal environmental conditions, such as the frequent lava flows re-ordering the landscape. However, these depictions belie the presence of persistent populations and novel agricultural intensification that emerged over a centuries? long occupation. Little is known about how hinterland communities conceived of elite authority at both the local and regional scales or how this conception differed from the royal centers. As my research argues, within Kaʻū, villages organized and interacted with royal centers, but maintained a degree of social and political autonomy. Through defining and deploying the concept of hinterland, this project focuses specific attention on the agency, authority, and hierarchy at multiple scales. Specifically, this research will analyze temporal change and regional diversity in settlement patterns and agricultural decisions, contextualized against expectations from World-Systems Theory and the Salubrious Core Hypothesis.

As with many parts of the world, studies of human ecodynamics in Hawaiʻi Island demonstrate the dynamic and nonlinear role that environmental variables serve in structuring the social decisions of human populations. Previous studies of traditional agricultural on systems on Hawaiʻi Island have focused heavily upon field systems supporting core, elite communities, such as Kohala and Kona. In contrast, archaeological remains of hinterland agricultural systems within Kaʻū remain understudied. The Kaʻū region is a young, volcanically active landscape, with nine diverse, but in many ways, marginal ecosystems. The region is on the southern tip of Hawaiʻi Island and straddles both the windward and leeward sides of the island. The diverse range of ecological niches offers numerous means to exploit agricultural potential.

This NSF doctoral dissertation improvement grant facilitated the completion of fieldwork and laboratory analysis for Belluzzo?s dissertation research. Research included pedestrian survey, targeted archaeological excavations, laboratory analysis, and geospatial modeling. The results provide nuance to existing models of settlement and community organization and suggest place-based, novel subsistence and settlement strategies.

At the transition between the Kaʻū and Kona districts on the slopes of the shield volcano, Mauna Loa, is the Manukā Natural Area Reserve (NAR), a State reserve extending from the coastline to 5,500 feet of elevation. The NAR aggregates two ahupua?a, or traditional land divisions from two separate districts into one administrative unit: Manukā from the District of Kaʻū and Kaulanamauna from the District of Kona. Manukā is geologically young, with flows predominately ranging from 0.75-3 ky. It receives between ~600-1,000 mm/yr of rainfall. Fourteen environmental communities, from coastal dry shrublands to montane mesic forests, are represented within the NAR. It is argued here that the diverse range of ecological niches offered varied agricultural and arboricultural opportunity.

Archaeological survey was conducted over 80 kilometers of linear transects, drawn from a 10% stratified random sampling of east-west transects. During the course of pedestrian survey, the investigations at Manukā identified over 400 archaeological features representing more than 150 archaeological sites. These findings included previously undocumented agricultural field system, habitation sites, and numerous heiau (temples) associated with agriculture, astronomical phenomenon, and active volcanism.

Additionally, a geological survey targeted individual volcanic flows to provide a geochemical characterization of the slope. Both geological samples and stone tools were analyzed using Energy Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (EDXRF) at the University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo. The results allowed conclusions to be made about the trade of stone tools, suggesting heavy use of certain locally produced stone tools, such as abraders, paired with the importation of non-locally sourced stone tools from Mauna Kea. Despite being a hinterland community, residents of Manukā were integrated into a broad system of island-wide exchange.

As a result of archaeological excavations, twenty-five samples of wood charcoal were identified to their corresponding taxon, identifying short-lived species suitable for radiometric dating while also providing a selective insight into flora present in the past within the project area. The radiocarbon dating results indicate both a broad settlement sequence, but also suggest the region was settled considerably earlier than existing models suggest. Likely, settlement decisions were guided by both push and pull factors and not strictly based on agricultural productivity or elite demands from the core.

Fieldwork was supported by archaeology students from the College of William & Mary and the University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo, which resulted in training opportunities that included pedestrian survey, archaeological excavation, site mapping, and the cataloging and curation of artifacts. The results have assisted NARS with their stewardship and land management efforts in the region. The results will be presented at local and national archaeology conferences, through huakaʻi (learning trips) with conservation and preservation professionals, and other stakeholders, and in publications currently being prepared. Several preliminary reports have been submitted to NARS. Additionally, several publications are currently in preparation.
